title: Can we make an Iron Man suit in real life which really works the same? - Quora

response.answer_text: IMHO I’m afraid not. We lack two crucial elements of Tony Stark’s iconic armor, and it’s likely we’ll always lack them because they don’t seem to be physically possible. The first is the repulsor ray. This is essentially a reactionless drive: it produces thrust without throwing mass out the rear as a rocket would, which violates Newton’s Third Law of Motion (which actually goes, per Wikipedia: “When one body exerts a force on a second body, the second body simultaneously exerts a force equal in magnitude and opposite in direction on the first body”). While it’s said that researchers from NASA on down are working on a space drive that appears to do what Iron Man’s repulsor ray does, this is very, very far from proven — and even if it were the drive in question is nowhere nearly as powerful as the hero’s tank-busting, SSTO (single stage to orbit) and back repulsor ray. The second is the ARC reactor. This is the glowing dingus in Iron Man’s chest that somehow generates enough power to charge the batteries that in turn power his battle armor, an output on the order of so many gigajoules per second. That’s the performance you’d expect of a small nuclear reactor, but Iron Man’s ARC reactor is far too small to be any such thing and no other physical process we know of (short of a matter/antimatter reaction, which Iron Man explicitly does not use) could generate such phenomenal power from such a tiny source. The closest thing to such a process in real life would be cold fusion, which purports to generate nuclear reactor-level power from a tabletop setup with none of the muss or fuss of the full-size reactor. Alas, cold fusion doesn’t seem to work; initial claims for it were quickly disproven, and to date it doesn’t actually exist outside of rumored work on LENR (lower-energy nuclear reactions) at the fringes of modern science. Everything else in Iron Man’s armor can be physically realized, but in nothing like as sleek, versatile or independent a form as the hero’s iconic battle suits.
